subject: linear_algebra
title: Linear Independence
contentHtml:
In linear algebra, a set of vectors is said to be linearly independent if none of the vectors can be expressed as a combination of the others.

This means that each vector in the set has its own unique direction and cannot be obtained by scaling or combining the other vectors.
latex: \( \mathbf{v}_1, \ldots, \mathbf{v}_n \) are linearly independent if \( c_1 \mathbf{v}_1 + \cdots + c_n \mathbf{v}_n = \mathbf{0} \) only when all coefficients \( c_i \) are zero.",
name: Linear Independence" },
intuition: Think of linear independence as the vectors being 'non-redundant'. Each vector has its own unique contribution to the set, and none can be eliminated or replaced without changing the overall behavior.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, linearly independent features are crucial for avoiding data redundancy and improving model performance.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse linear independence with orthogonality. Orthogonal vectors are perpendicular to each other, but not necessarily linearly independent.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Linear Independence
contentHtml:
A set of vectors is said to be linearly independent if none of the vectors can be expressed as a combination of the others.

In other words, if you have a set of vectors \{\mathbf{v}_1,\ldots,\mathbf{v}_n\}, then they are linearly independent if and only if the equation

a_1\mathbf{v}_1+\cdots+a_n\mathbf{v}_n=\mathbf{0}has only the trivial solution (a_1,\ldots,a_n)=(0,\ldots,0).

",
name: Linear Independence Equation" },
intuition: Think of linear independence like a set of unique building blocks. Each block can't be broken down into smaller pieces using the other blocks.

commonMistakes: Thinking that two vectors are linearly independent just because they're not parallel

subject: linear_algebra
title: Linear Independence Theorem
contentHtml: The linear independence theorem is a fundamental concept in vector spaces that helps us determine whether a set of vectors is independent or not.

theorem.statement: \[ A set S of vectors in V is linearly independent if and only if the only solution to the equation Ax = 0 is x = 0. \]

subject: linear_algebra
title: Linear Independence
contentHtml:
A set of vectors is said to be linearly independent if none of the vectors can be expressed as a linear combination of the others.

  • This means that each vector in the set has its own unique direction and cannot be replaced by a combination of the other vectors.

formula.latex: \[\mathbf{v}_1, \mathbf{v}_2, \ldots, \mathbf{v}_n \text{ are linearly independent } \Leftrightarrow \text{ no } c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_n \text{ exist such that }\sum_{i=1}^n c_i \mathbf{v}_i = \mathbf{0}\]
formula.name: Linear Independence

theorem.statement: \[\text{A set of vectors is linearly independent if and only if the only solution to }\sum_{i=1}^n c_i \mathbf{v}_i = \mathbf{0}\text{ is when all }c_i = 0.\]

intuition: Linear independence is crucial in many areas of mathematics, including linear algebra, differential equations, and machine learning.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, linearly independent features are essential for avoiding issues like multicollinearity.

solutionHtml:
To test for linear independence, we can use the following steps:

  1. Assume that \mathbf{v}_1 is a linear combination of the other vectors.

  2. This means there exist scalars c_2, c_3, ..., c_n such that

    \mathbf{v}_1 = c_2 \mathbf{v}_2 + c_3 \mathbf{v}_3 + ... + c_n \mathbf{v}_n.

  3. This is a contradiction, since we assumed that \mathbf{v}_1 was not a linear combination of the other vectors.

  4. Therefore, our assumption must be false, and \mathbf{v}_1 is indeed linearly independent from the others.

",
answerShort: The set of vectors is linearly independent if no vector can be expressed as a combination of the others." },

problem.statementHtml: Given the vectors \mathbf{a} = [1, 0, 0], \mathbf{b} = [0, 1, 0], and \mathbf{c} = [0, 0, 1], determine whether they are linearly independent.
hints: Hint: Think about the geometric meaning of independence
problem.solutionHtml:
To test for linear independence, we can try to express one vector as a combination of the others. For example, let's see if \mathbf{a} can be expressed as a combination of \mathbf{b} and \mathbf{c}. We have:

  • \[1 = 0x_2 + 0x_3\]

This is not possible, so we know that \mathbf{a} cannot be expressed as a combination of \mathbf{b} and \mathbf{c}. Similarly, we can show that none of the vectors can be expressed as a combination of the others.
problem.answerShort: The given vectors are linearly independent.

problem.statementHtml: Given the vectors \mathbf{a} = [1, 2], \mathbf{b} = [3, 4], and \mathbf{c} = [5, 6], determine if they are linearly independent.
hints: Hint: Check if one vector is a scalar multiple of another
problem.solutionHtml:
To test for linear independence, we can try to express one vector as a combination of the others. Let's say we want to express \mathbf{a} as a combination:

  • We can write \mathbf{a} = c_1 \mathbf{b} + c_2 \mathbf{c}, where c_1 and c_2 are scalars.
  • We can substitute the values of \mathbf{b} and \mathbf{c}: [1, 2] = c_1 [3, 4] + c_2 [5, 6].
  • We can equate corresponding components: 1 = 3c_1 + 5c_2 and 2 = 4c_1 + 6c_2.
  • We can solve this system of equations to find the values of c_1 and c_2. This will tell us if we can express \mathbf{a} as a combination of \mathbf{b} and \mathbf{c}.
problem.answerShort: No, the vectors are linearly independent
